keyText:
blow up.

if something blows up, or if someone blows something up, it explodes and is destroyed.

Terrorists had threatened to blow up the embassy
wordDefinition: if something blows up, or if someone blows something up, it explodes and is destroyed
wordExamples: Terrorists had threatened to blow up the embassy

keyText:
break down.

if a machine or vehicle breaks down, it stops working.

The car broke down just outside Omaha
wordDefinition: if a machine or vehicle breaks down, it stops working
wordExamples: The car broke down just outside Omaha

keyText:
break up.

to break something to make smaller pieces.

Break the chocolate up into squares
wordDefinition: to break something to make smaller pieces
wordExamples: Break the chocolate up into squares

keyText:
call off.

to decide that something will not happen.

She’s called off the wedding
wordDefinition: to decide that something will not happen
wordExamples: She’s called off the wedding

keyText:
carry on.

to continue doing something.

Carry on. You’re doing fine
wordDefinition: to continue doing something
wordExamples: Carry on. You’re doing fine

keyText:
catch up.

to go faster so that you reach the person or vehicle in front of you.

catch up with: We left first, but they caught up with us
wordDefinition: to go faster so that you reach the person or vehicle in front of you
wordExamples: catch up with: We left first, but they caught up with us

keyText:
cheer up.

to become less sad, or to make someone feel less sad.

I tried to cheer him up, but he just kept staring out the window
wordDefinition: to become less sad, or to make someone feel less sad
wordExamples: I tried to cheer him up, but he just kept staring out the window

keyText:
come across.

to meet someone, or to find something by chance.

I came across a word I’d never seen before
wordDefinition: to meet someone, or to find something by chance
wordExamples: I came across a word I’d never seen before

keyText:
come up with.

to think of something such as an idea or a plan.

Is that the best you can come up with?
wordDefinition: to think of something such as an idea or a plan
wordExamples: Is that the best you can come up with?

keyText:
count on.

to depend on someone to do what you want or expect them to do for you.

The whole team was counting on me, and I let them down
wordDefinition: to depend on someone to do what you want or expect them to do for you
wordExamples: The whole team was counting on me, and I let them down

keyText:
figure out.

to be able to understand something or to solve a problem.

We had to figure out the connection between the two events
wordDefinition: to be able to understand something or to solve a problem
wordExamples: We had to figure out the connection between the two events

keyText:
fill in.

to add information such as your name or address in the empty spaces on an official document.

Please fill in your name and address in the space provided
wordDefinition: to add information such as your name or address in the empty spaces on an official document
wordExamples: Please fill in your name and address in the space provided

keyText:
get along.

if people get along, they like each other and are friendly to each other.

Richard and his sister don’t get along
wordDefinition: if people get along, they like each other and are friendly to each other
wordExamples: Richard and his sister don’t get along

keyText:
give up.

to stop doing something that you do regularly.

His wife finally persuaded him to give up smoking
wordDefinition: to stop doing something that you do regularly
wordExamples: His wife finally persuaded him to give up smoking

keyText:
go on.

to continue happening or doing something as before.

The meeting went on a lot longer than I expected
wordDefinition: to continue happening or doing something as before
wordExamples: The meeting went on a lot longer than I expected

keyText:
hang up.

to stop using a telephone at the end of a conversation.

Greg hung up and sat back in his chair
wordDefinition: to stop using a telephone at the end of a conversation
wordExamples: Greg hung up and sat back in his chair

keyText:
hold on.

to hold something tightly or carefully so that you do not drop it or do not fall.

hold on tight: Hold on tight everyone, the boat’s getting ready to go
wordDefinition: to hold something tightly or carefully so that you do not drop it or do not fall
wordExamples: hold on tight: Hold on tight everyone, the boat’s getting ready to go

keyText:
keep up with.

to make progress or learn at the same speed as someone or something.

We always try to keep up with our stakeholders
wordDefinition: to make progress or learn at the same speed as someone or something
wordExamples: We always try to keep up with our stakeholders

keyText:
let down.

to make someone disappointed by not doing something that they are expecting you to do.

The kids will be let down when they hear you can’t come after all
wordDefinition: to make someone disappointed by not doing something that they are expecting you to do
wordExamples: The kids will be let down when they hear you can’t come after all

keyText:
look after.

to take care of someone or something and make certain that they have everything they need.

It’s hard work looking after three children all day
wordDefinition: to take care of someone or something and make certain that they have everything they need
wordExamples: It’s hard work looking after three children all day

keyText:
look for.

to search for someone or something.

I’m looking for Jim. Have you seen him?
wordDefinition: to search for someone or something
wordExamples: I’m looking for Jim. Have you seen him?

keyText:
look forward to.

to feel happy and excited about something that is going to happen.

He had worked hard and was looking forward to his retirement
wordDefinition: to feel happy and excited about something that is going to happen
wordExamples: He had worked hard and was looking forward to his retirement

keyText:
pass away.

to die. This word is used to avoid saying “die” when you think this might upset someone.

He passed away in his sleep at the age of eighty-four
wordDefinition: to die. This word is used to avoid saying “die” when you think this might upset someone
wordExamples: He passed away in his sleep at the age of eighty-four

keyText:
pass out.

to suddenly become unconscious, for example because you are too hot.

People everywhere were passing out from the heat
wordDefinition: to suddenly become unconscious, for example because you are too hot
wordExamples: People everywhere were passing out from the heat

keyText:
pick up.

to lift someone or something up from a surface.

He picked the phone up as soon as it rang
wordDefinition: to lift someone or something up from a surface
wordExamples: He picked the phone up as soon as it rang

keyText:
pull over.

if a vehicle or driver pulls over, they stop by the side of the road.

Let’s pull over and have a look at the map
wordDefinition: if a vehicle or driver pulls over, they stop by the side of the road
wordExamples: Let’s pull over and have a look at the map

keyText:
put down.

to put someone or something onto a surface, especially the floor.

Emma put her bag down and went upstairs
wordDefinition: to put someone or something onto a surface, especially the floor
wordExamples: Emma put her bag down and went upstairs

keyText:
put off.

to delay doing something, especially because you do not want to do it.

I was trying to put off the moment when I would have to leave
wordDefinition: to delay doing something, especially because you do not want to do it
wordExamples: I was trying to put off the moment when I would have to leave

keyText:
put on.

to cover a part of your body with a piece of clothing or jewelry so that you are wearing it.

Dorothy put on her coat and went out
wordDefinition: to cover a part of your body with a piece of clothing or jewelry so that you are wearing it
wordExamples: Dorothy put on her coat and went out

keyText:
put out.

to make something stop burning.

It took firefighters three hours to put out the blaze
wordDefinition: to make something stop burning
wordExamples: It took firefighters three hours to put out the blaze

keyText:
put up with.

to accept someone or something unpleasant in a patient way.

How has Jan put up with him for so long?
wordDefinition: to accept someone or something unpleasant in a patient way
wordExamples: How has Jan put up with him for so long?

keyText:
run out of.

to use all of something and not have any left.

Many schools are running out of money
wordDefinition: to use all of something and not have any left
wordExamples: Many schools are running out of money

keyText:
take away.

a restaurant or shop selling cooked food to be eaten elsewhere.
wordDefinition: a restaurant or shop selling cooked food to be eaten elsewhere

keyText:
take off.

to remove something, especially a piece of clothing.

I’d better take my shoes off
wordDefinition: to remove something, especially a piece of clothing
wordExamples: I’d better take my shoes off

keyText:
throw up.

if you throw up or throw something up, food and drink comes back up from your stomach and out of your mouth.

I feel terrible, I’ve been throwing up all night!
wordDefinition: if you throw up or throw something up, food and drink comes back up from your stomach and out of your mouth
wordExamples: I feel terrible, I’ve been throwing up all night!

keyText:
try on.

to put on a piece of clothing in order to see how it looks and whether it fits.

What a cute dress! Why don’t you try it on?
wordDefinition: to put on a piece of clothing in order to see how it looks and whether it fits
wordExamples: What a cute dress! Why don’t you try it on?

keyText:
turn down.

to not accept an offer or request.

How could you turn down such a fantastic job?
wordDefinition: to not accept an offer or request
wordExamples: How could you turn down such a fantastic job?

keyText:
turn off.

to stop a piece of equipment working temporarily by pressing a button or by moving a switch.

Will you turn the television off, please?
wordDefinition: to stop a piece of equipment working temporarily by pressing a button or by moving a switch
wordExamples: Will you turn the television off, please?

keyText:
turn on.

to make a piece of equipment start working by pressing a button or moving a switch.

Is your computer turned on?
wordDefinition: to make a piece of equipment start working by pressing a button or moving a switch
wordExamples: Is your computer turned on?

keyText:
turn up.

to increase the amount of sound, heat, or light produced by a piece of equipment by pressing a button or moving a switch.

Can you turn the volume up a little?
wordDefinition: to increase the amount of sound, heat, or light produced by a piece of equipment by pressing a button or moving a switch
wordExamples: Can you turn the volume up a little?

keyText:
warm up.

to become warm.

I’ll warm up some soup for lunch
wordDefinition: to become warm
wordExamples: I’ll warm up some soup for lunch

keyText:
watch out.

to be careful.

Watch out – you’re going to hit that car!
wordDefinition: to be careful
wordExamples: Watch out – you’re going to hit that car!

keyText:
work out.

to deal with a problem in a satisfactory way.

We’ve worked out our differences
wordDefinition: to deal with a problem in a satisfactory way
wordExamples: We’ve worked out our differences
